stream_context.summary: Kaze continues development on a factory-themed area (Course 15), coordinating with Biobak to fix missing textures and iterate on environmental assets. He adjusts a King Bob-omb-style boss (“Bokwang”) behavior and feedback visuals (orange blink/explosion color), tweaks the fight flow (adds a post-switch wall and an item box), and discusses gating the boss so it won’t respawn once the Bomb Cap is unlocked. He also shares a rough timeline for the next public demo release (tied to upcoming YouTube videos) and experiments with a more advanced per-room lighting/material multiplication approach for a bombable wall asset.
stream_context.significance_reason: Includes concrete feature decisions (boss respawn/permanent death, fight flow tweaks), a specific demo release window tied to video production, and real collaboration checkpoints with Biobak (textures, asset removals, bombable wall).

findings.summary: Kaze identifies missing textures in a shared Blender file (factorycanon.blend) and pings Biobak to supply them, indicating active back-and-forth on the factory environment asset pipeline.
Kaze decides the boss (“Bokwang”/new King Bob-omb) should not spawn if the player already has the Bomb Cap unlocked, and that the boss should die permanently (one-time completion).
findings.quote: The idea is that he doesn't spawn if you have the bomb cap unlocked, and he dies permanently.

findings.summary: A prior visual feedback effect on the boss (body blinking/orange when hit via primitive color changes) was lost; Kaze restores the effect while avoiding unintended behavior (e.g., making the boss die in one hit).
Kaze tweaks boss feedback to turn orange on explosion/death and adjusts the death animation timing/feel, validating the look in-game after changes.

Kaze adds a wall that rises immediately after pressing a switch, changing the room’s flow so the player must break through afterward; he notes the fight/sequence shouldn’t be “free” and adds an item box to address a missing resource opportunity in the following room.

Kaze calls out a micro-optimization he previously made as not worth it because it saves less than half a microsecond but makes code harder to read, showing a tradeoff preference toward maintainability during late-stage polish.
findings.quote: It's a really silly optimization... it makes the code harder to read.

findings.summary: Kaze gives a concrete dependency-based timeline for the next demo: it’s essentially done, but release is blocked by scheduled video releases and editor availability; he estimates the demo could land around late December (around Dec 28).
Kaze highlights a stage gimmick he finds particularly fun: completing the same area both forward and backward, because obstacles ‘work for you’ differently and the vibe changes substantially.

Kaze proposes an advanced material/lighting approach for a bombable wall: using grayscale textures and multiple multiplication passes so primitive color can represent per-room lighting (e.g., red room vs other rooms), with depth-based falloff plus normal lighting.
findings.quote: The primitive color can be the lighting in the room.

findings.summary: Kaze notes unresolved technical/art issues to fix later (e.g., cap switch colors showing red across variants; one gear rotating on the wrong axis; object spawn heights/positions needing dynamic placement), but defers them to avoid derailing the session.

biobak.summary: Biobak is directly involved in the factory asset pipeline: Kaze requests missing textures for factorycanon.blend and receives/validates texture updates in real time.
Biobak has been reworking the stage; Kaze references “Biobak’s rework of the stage” as a major ongoing dependency that may finish after Kaze completes core gameplay work.
Biobak previously requested removal of “wall gears” in the factory; Kaze confirms they were intentionally removed and checks whether any were missed.

Kaze asks whether Biobak created the bombable wall asset; discussion suggests the wall may need geometry/texture/lighting updates and its animation workflow would need to be relearned if geometry changes.

key_stories.title: Making the factory boss stateful and restoring hit-feedback visuals
key_stories.summary: Kaze notices a previously existing visual effect on the boss (orange blink via primitive color) no longer works and investigates how to restore it without breaking gameplay. In parallel, he finalizes the intended progression rule: once the Bomb Cap is unlocked, the boss should no longer spawn and should be permanently defeated.
key_stories.challenge: Restore satisfying damage feedback (orange blink/explosion color) while keeping correct boss health behavior and integrating a one-time, progression-based encounter rule.
key_stories.process: He traces which material/color indices control the effect, chooses an orange explosion/death color, adjusts boss death behavior, tests the animation in-game, and clarifies the permanent-death/no-respawn condition tied to Bomb Cap unlock.
key_stories.outcome: Boss hit/death feedback is restored/adjusted, and the encounter is framed as a one-time event that stops spawning after Bomb Cap progression.
key_stories.key_quote: The idea is that he doesn't spawn if you have the bomb cap unlocked, and he dies permanently.

key_stories.title: Upgrading a bombable wall with per-room lighting via material multiplication
key_stories.summary: While iterating on a bombable wall that feels visually ‘unfitting,’ Kaze sketches a more sophisticated approach to match lighting across different rooms. He proposes using grayscale textures and multiple multiplication passes so primitive color can serve as room-specific lighting, with additional depth-based adjustments.
key_stories.challenge: Make an interactive wall asset read well across multiple lighting contexts without creating separate bespoke textures for every room.
key_stories.process: He outlines a pipeline combining grayscale textures, multi-stage multiplication (texture*texture*shade/primitive), and using primitive color as a per-room lighting driver (e.g., ‘red room’), then adding falloff as the brick goes further in.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete plan for a higher-fidelity, scalable lighting solution, pending implementation/tool stability (he ends stream early before completing it).
key_stories.key_quote: The primitive color can be the lighting in the room.

open_questions.topic: Boss progression rule (no spawn after Bomb Cap / permanent defeat)
open_questions.context: Kaze states the boss should not spawn after Bomb Cap unlock and should die permanently, implying persistent save-state changes and a deliberate ‘world evolves with you’ philosophy.
questions: What player-experience goal does ‘permanent death/no respawn after unlock’ serve in Return to Yoshi’s Island (immersion, pacing, reducing repetition, narrative logic)?
How is this persistence implemented technically in the decomp hack (save flags, star/mission state, custom save data)?
Are there other encounters or setpieces planned to behave this way (one-time bosses, one-time environmental changes)?

open_questions.topic: Course 15 design intent: forward and backward completion
open_questions.context: Kaze calls out a level concept where traversing the same space in reverse is intentionally fun because obstacles behave differently and change the vibe.
questions: Was the forward/backward traversal built into the level from the start, or discovered during testing and then designed around?
